articles.headline: Goldman, Citi, UBS ... and a Guy in an Office
articles.snippet: Paul J. Taubman has single-handedly accounted for $175 billion in deals over the last year, which has had Wall Street bankers buzzing with a mix of admiration and envy.
articles.abstract: Paul J. Taubman has single-handedly accounted for $175 billion in deals over the last year, which has had Wall Street bankers buzzing with a mix of admiration and envy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anyone looking at the mergers and acquisitions “league tables” — the Wall Street equivalent of Major League Baseball’s standings — during this hot year for merger activity would find the usual suspects: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs vying for the top spot, with other big brand-name firms jockeying to fill the coveted top 10.

articles.headline: Taking a Job Out of the Financial Equation
articles.snippet: As they tackle numerous financial issues, some baby boomers considering retirement are hiring life counselors to help them plot their futures.
articles.abstract: As they tackle numerous financial issues, some baby boomers considering retirement are hiring life counselors to help them plot their futures.
articles.lead_paragraph: No pensions. Roller-coaster retirement accounts. Longer lives and higher health care costs. Aging parents. Children in college. A will to work but fewer jobs to be had.

articles.headline: Heartbleed Internet Security Flaw Used in Attack
articles.snippet: On Friday, cybersecurity experts said they had evidence of the first confirmed attack on a major corporation using the Heartbleed bug.
articles.abstract: On Friday, cybersecurity experts said they had evidence of the first confirmed attack on a major corporation using the Heartbleed bug.
articles.lead_paragraph: Within 24 hours of the Heartbleed bug’s disclosure last week, an attacker used it to break into a major corporation, security experts said Friday.

articles.headline: The Re-education of a Brash Young Stock Picker
articles.snippet: Despite all his success picking stocks, Randy Kurtz now mostly buys index and exchange-traded funds for his clients.
articles.abstract: Despite all his success picking stocks, Randy Kurtz now mostly buys index and exchange-traded funds for his clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, Randy Kurtz made an extraordinary bet on himself, the stock market and his ability to pick a few winners.

articles.headline: Swim to Sea? These Salmon Are Catching a Lift
articles.snippet: California’s drought has left rivers too shallow for salmon, so the government is trucking and barging them to the sea in the hope they will return.
articles.abstract: California’s drought has left rivers too shallow for salmon, so the government is trucking and barging them to the sea in the hope they will return.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO VISTA, Calif. — As the Merva W puttered down the Sacramento River, it looked like any other dowdy fishing vessel headed toward the Golden Gate Bridge. But no other boat had as surprising a cargo or as unusual a mission: The Merva W was giving 100,000 young salmon a lift to the Pacific in the hope of keeping them alive.

articles.headline: Heartbleed Highlights a Contradiction in the Web
articles.snippet: The bug that rattled the Internet last week exposed the paradox that some of the web’s most crucial coding depends on the efforts of volunteers.
articles.abstract: The bug that rattled the Internet last week exposed the paradox that some of the web’s most crucial coding depends on the efforts of volunteers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Heartbleed bug that made news last week drew attention to one of the least understood elements of the Internet: Much of the invisible backbone of websites from Google to Amazon to the Federal Bureau of Investigation was built by volunteer programmers in what is known as the open-source community.

articles.headline: Health Care Spending’s Recent Surge Stirs Unease
articles.snippet: Policy experts wonder whether the government and private businesses can control spending as the economy gets stronger and millions more Americans gain coverage.
articles.abstract: Policy experts wonder whether the government and private businesses can control spending as the economy gets stronger and millions more Americans gain coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s back.

articles.headline: Covert Inquiry by F.B.I. Rattles 9/11 Tribunals
articles.snippet: The F.B.I.’s inquiry became the focus of the pretrial hearings at Guantánamo this week, after the contractor who was visited by the F.B.I. disclosed it to the defense team.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I.’s inquiry became the focus of the pretrial hearings at Guantánamo this week, after the contractor who was visited by the F.B.I. disclosed it to the defense team.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two weeks ago, a pair of F.B.I. agents appeared unannounced at the door of a member of the defense team for one of the men accused of plotting the 9/11 terrorist attacks. As a contractor working with the defense team at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the man was bound by the same confidentiality rules as a lawyer. But the agents wanted to talk.

articles.headline: Banks Cling to Bundles Holding Risk
articles.snippet: Banks are fighting imposition of a part of the Volcker Rule that restricts trading in collateralized loan obligations, or C.L.O.s.
articles.abstract: Banks are fighting imposition of a part of the Volcker Rule that restricts trading in collateralized loan obligations, or C.L.O.s.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Volcker Rule doesn’t go into effect until 2015, but that hasn’t stopped big bankers and their supporters in Washington from trying to undermine it.

articles.headline: In Slovakia, Real Lottery Prize Goes to Tax Man
articles.snippet: The idea of a new lottery in Slovakia is to encourage citizens to collect sales receipts and register them with the government, forcing restaurant and shop owners to pay the taxes they owe.
articles.abstract: The idea of a new lottery in Slovakia is to encourage citizens to collect sales receipts and register them with the government, forcing restaurant and shop owners to pay the taxes they owe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — When Jozef Lazarcik, a 35-year-old factory worker, heard his number called on national television here recently, he pumped his fists, hardly believing his luck.
articles.byline: By Suzanne Daley and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: Comcast’s Real Repairman
articles.snippet: David Cohen, Comcast’s executive vice president, is the point man for moving deals like the one for Time Warner Cable past regulatory hurdles.
articles.abstract: David Cohen, Comcast’s executive vice president, is the point man for moving deals like the one for Time Warner Cable past regulatory hurdles.
articles.lead_paragraph: One morning late last month, David L. Cohen took a seat in a conference room atop Comcast’s corporate headquarters in Philadelphia, the tallest building in the city, and was handed a binder of architectural drawings. The plans were for a second Comcast skyscraper, taller than the first, because the growing company needs more space.

articles.headline: Taking On Adam Smith (and Karl Marx)
articles.snippet: With his book “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Thomas Piketty has written a blockbuster in the world of economics.
articles.abstract: With his book “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Thomas Piketty has written a blockbuster in the world of economics.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Thomas Piketty turned 18 in 1989, when the Berlin Wall fell, so he was spared the tortured, decades-long French intellectual debate about the virtues and vices of communism. Even more telling, he remembers, was a trip he took with a close friend to Romania in early 1990, after the collapse of the Soviet empire.

articles.headline: Republicans See Political Wedge in Common Core
articles.snippet: The Common Core, a set of national educational standards, is seen by some conservatives as federal overreach. But in contrast to the Affordable Care Act, it has Republican defenders.
articles.abstract: The Common Core, a set of national educational standards, is seen by some conservatives as federal overreach. But in contrast to the Affordable Care Act, it has Republican defenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The health care law may be Republicans’ favorite weapon against Democrats this year, but there is another issue roiling their party and shaping the establishment-versus-grass-roots divide ahead of the 2016 presidential primaries: the Common Core.

articles.headline: In Cold War Echo, Obama Strategy Writes Off Putin
articles.snippet: President Obama wants to isolate Russia by cutting off its economic and political ties to the outside world, limiting its expansionist ambitions and effectively making it a pariah state.
articles.abstract: President Obama wants to isolate Russia by cutting off its economic and political ties to the outside world, limiting its expansionist ambitions and effectively making it a pariah state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as the crisis in Ukraine continues to defy easy resolution, President Obama and his national security team are looking beyond the immediate conflict to forge a new long-term approach to Russia that applies an updated version of the Cold War strategy of containment.

articles.headline: Investigating Family’s Wealth, China’s Leader Signals a Change
articles.snippet: A corruption inquiry targeting the retired Communist Party leader Zhou Yongkang and his family could challenge a tacit rule that has allowed elite clans to accumulate vast wealth.
articles.abstract: A corruption inquiry targeting the retired Communist Party leader Zhou Yongkang and his family could challenge a tacit rule that has allowed elite clans to accumulate vast wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — His son landed contracts to sell equipment to state oil fields and thousands of filling stations across China. His son’s mother-in-law held stakes in pipelines and natural gas pumps from Sichuan Province in the west to the southern isle of Hainan. And his sister-in-law, working from one of Beijing’s most prestigious office buildings, invested in mines, property and energy projects.
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe, Chris Buckley and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: Sending Alerts Instead, G.M. Delayed Car Recalls
articles.snippet: A Times analysis shows that General Motors repeatedly used technical service bulletins as a stopgap safety measure instead of ordering timely recalls.
articles.abstract: A Times analysis shows that General Motors repeatedly used technical service bulletins as a stopgap safety measure instead of ordering timely recalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first word from General Motors that the Chevrolet Cobalt had a dangerous safety problem came nine years ago, in a letter to dealers warning them that the cars could suddenly stall because of faulty ignition switches.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Friends, and Influence, for Sale Online
articles.snippet: By using social media bots, celebrities, politicians and others can falsely inflate the number of friends and followers they have, possibly swaying public opinion about a new song — or a policy position.
articles.abstract: By using social media bots, celebrities, politicians and others can falsely inflate the number of friends and followers they have, possibly swaying public opinion about a new song — or a policy position.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whoever said, “Money can’t buy you friends,” clearly hasn’t been on the Internet recently.

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley Thriller, a Settlement May Preclude the Finale
articles.snippet: Four leading tech companies are pushing to settle a class-action suit with several noteworthy angles, including questions over employee rights and the death of a programmer who helped set the case in motion.
articles.abstract: Four leading tech companies are pushing to settle a class-action suit with several noteworthy angles, including questions over employee rights and the death of a programmer who helped set the case in motion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After years of legal skirmishes, four leading Silicon Valley companies are scheduled to go on trial next month on claims of conspiring to keep their employees down.

articles.headline: Errors Mounted as Chaos Ruled Capsizing Ferry
articles.snippet: A portrait of chaos is emerging from crew members, survivors and a transcript of the vessel’s final 40 minutes of communications with emergency dispatchers.
articles.abstract: A portrait of chaos is emerging from crew members, survivors and a transcript of the vessel’s final 40 minutes of communications with emergency dispatchers.
articles.lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — Of all the images from the loss of a ferry in the cold waters off the southwest coast of South Korea last week, perhaps none have angered South Koreans more than those of the captain and his key crew members awkwardly and quickly fleeing their half-submerged vessel to the safety of a rescue boat, even as hundreds of their passengers remained trapped inside.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun, Kirk Semple and Su-Hyun Lee

articles.headline: Aereo Case Will Shape TV’s Future
articles.snippet: A lot of people will be watching to see how the Supreme Court rules over the legality of Aereo because of what it could mean for the broader media ecosystem.
articles.abstract: A lot of people will be watching to see how the Supreme Court rules over the legality of Aereo because of what it could mean for the broader media ecosystem.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout America’s business history, the victories and spoils went to the visionaries who made all manner of things — actual things like cars, pharmaceuticals and entertainment.

articles.headline: California’s Thirsting Farmland
articles.snippet: California farmers have never relied only on rain. But given a prolonged drought and environmental regulations, the jockeying for water is becoming more intense.
articles.abstract: California farmers have never relied only on rain. But given a prolonged drought and environmental regulations, the jockeying for water is becoming more intense.
articles.lead_paragraph: FIREBAUGH, Calif. — This summer, Todd Allen’s only crop will be Pima cotton.

articles.headline: Ukrainian Gas Broker Faces Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Dmytro Firtash has made billions brokering gas deals, but he now faces both a criminal indictment and a racketeering lawsuit in United States courts.
articles.abstract: Dmytro Firtash has made billions brokering gas deals, but he now faces both a criminal indictment and a racketeering lawsuit in United States courts.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Gas pricing wars between Russia and Ukraine, like the one breaking out now, have generally ended badly for the two countries and Gazprom, the Russian energy monopoly.

articles.headline: Photos Link Masked Men in East Ukraine to Russia
articles.snippet: Photos and descriptions suggest that many of the mysteriously well-armed gunmen in eastern Ukraine are Russian military and intelligence forces.
articles.abstract: Photos and descriptions suggest that many of the mysteriously well-armed gunmen in eastern Ukraine are Russian military and intelligence forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — For two weeks, the mysteriously well-armed, professional gunmen known as “green men” have seized Ukrainian government sites in town after town, igniting a brush fire of separatist unrest across eastern Ukraine. Strenuous denials from the Kremlin have closely followed each accusation by Ukrainian officials that the world was witnessing a stealthy invasion by Russian forces.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins, Michael R. Gordon and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: 50 Years Into the War on Poverty, Hardship Hits Back
articles.snippet: A half-century after President Lyndon B. Johnson declared “war on poverty,” McDowell County, W.Va., is a sobering reminder of how much remains broken, in drearily familiar ways and utterly unexpected ones.
articles.abstract: A half-century after President Lyndon B. Johnson declared “war on poverty,” McDowell County, W.Va., is a sobering reminder of how much remains broken, in drearily familiar ways and utterly unexpected ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: TWIN BRANCH, W.Va. — When people visit with friends and neighbors in southern West Virginia, where paved roads give way to dirt before winding steeply up wooded hollows, the talk is often of lives that never got off the ground.

articles.headline: Jeb Bush’s Rush to Make Money May Be Hurdle
articles.snippet: Mr. Bush’s efforts to capitalize on his résumé and reputation have thrust him into situations that may prove challenging to explain should he mount a campaign for the presidency.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bush’s efforts to capitalize on his résumé and reputation have thrust him into situations that may prove challenging to explain should he mount a campaign for the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it sought to recruit well-heeled investors, an untested and unprofitable Miami company named InnoVida brought aboard a trusted Florida figure in 2007: Jeb Bush, the former governor and the brother of a sitting president.

articles.headline: U.S. Promotes Network to Foil Digital Spying
articles.snippet: The State Department and other agencies are spending millions around the world to finance local systems, called mesh networks, as more secure alternatives to the Internet.
articles.abstract: The State Department and other agencies are spending millions around the world to finance local systems, called mesh networks, as more secure alternatives to the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAYADA, Tunisia — This Mediterranean fishing town, with its low, whitewashed buildings and sleepy port, is an unlikely spot for an experiment in rewiring the global Internet. But residents here have a surprising level of digital savvy and sharp memories of how the Internet can be misused.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and James Glanz

articles.headline: Bankers in Hong Kong Join Fight Against Mainland Influence
articles.snippet: Several dozen members of Hong Kong’s financial class hope more of their number will join Occupy Central, which plans protests demanding unfettered elections.
articles.abstract: Several dozen members of Hong Kong’s financial class hope more of their number will join Occupy Central, which plans protests demanding unfettered elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In this city awash with money from mainland China, a former hedge fund manager hopes to incite a political awakening among the bankers, stockbrokers and financial traders whose livelihoods have become increasingly enmeshed in the mainland’s cash and influence.

articles.headline: Barclays Said to Join Commodity Exodus
articles.snippet: Investment banks, which rushed into the new territory of physical commodities starting at the turn of the century, are now beating a retreat.
articles.abstract: Investment banks, which rushed into the new territory of physical commodities starting at the turn of the century, are now beating a retreat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investment banks, which rushed into the new territory of physical commodities starting at the turn of the century, are now beating a retreat.
